lines.text: My dear partner, when what's left of you gets around to what's left to be gotten, what's left to be gotten won't be worth getting, whatever it is you've got left.
When I figure out what that means I'll come up with a crushing reply.
How do you do?
Mutual, I'm sure.

I want you to get married. I want you to have nine children. And if you only spend five minutes a day with each kid, that's forty-five minutes, and I'd at least have time to go out and get a massage or something.
You don't expect me to get serious with the kind of characters you and Rita have been throwing at me, do you?
Well, there've been some nice girls, too, you know.
Oh yeah, yeah. Like that nuclear scientist we just met out in the hall.
All right, they didn't go to college. They didn't go to Smith.
Go to Smith? She couldn't even spell it.
Oh, that's very funny. Ho, ho, ho. The crooner is now becoming the comic.

[finding Judy and Phil embracing]
What is this? The best two outta three?
I guess I got carried away.
Yes, she carried me right with her - I don't weigh very much.

[to Phil and Judy]
You ought to be horsewhipped. First you, and then you, and then you again.
Well, I like that! Without so much as a "kiss my foot" or "have an apple."
It's cozier, isn't it? Boy, girl, boy, girl?
How much is "wow"?
It's right in between, uh, between "ouch" and "boing".
Wow!
We like to take care of our friends.
We're practically strangers!
Well... well, we'd like to take care of that, too.
But... but you might get yourself in an awful jam. Why should you? I mean, what's in it for you?
Forty-five minutes all to myself.

[to Judy]
You outta consider yourself plenty lucky! You might have been stuck with this weirdsmobile for life!
Oh, Phil, when are you gonna learn that girls like that are a dime a dozen?
Please, don't quote me the price when I haven't got the time.

Miss Haynes, if you're ever under a falling building and somebody runs up and offers to pick you up and carry you to safety, don't think, don't pause, don't hesitate for a moment, just spit in his eye.
What did that mean?
It means we're going to Vermont.
We wouldn't be any good as generals.
You weren't any good as privates

[Regarding Phil]
I don't know what you see in this long drink of charged water but, honestly, after you get to know him he's almost endurable.
[Bob leaves to go make a phone call]

[sighs]
I don't know what he's up to, but he's got that Rodgers and Hammerstein look again.
Is that bad?
Not bad, but always expensive.
How do you do?
Mutual, I'm sure.
How can a guy THAT ugly have the nerve to have sisters?
Very brave parents, I guess.
Give me one reason, one good reason, why we should spend our last two hours in Florida looking at the sisters of Freckle-Face Haynes, the dog-faced boy.
Let's just say we're doing it for a pal in the army, huh?
Well, it's not good, but it's a reason.
Imagine a girl in show business today wanting to settle down and raising a family. It's so refreshing, isn't it?

[into his water glass]
Pushing, pushing.

[describing his kind to Judy]
Well, I'm, uh, more the 'I-don't-mind-pushing-my-best-friend-into-but-I'm-scared-stiff-when-I-get-anywhere-close-to-it-myselfing' kind.

[about the train tickets]
I don't seem to have them. Maybe you got 'em, Bob.
ME? You crazy? I saw you put 'em in your pocket.
Well, they're gone. There're gone. I must have left 'em in my girdle.
Well, I've got a feeling I'm not gonna like it.
I got a feeling you're gonna hate it.
Well, what am I doin' it for?
Let's just say we're...

[together]
... doing it for an old pal in the army... yeah.

[singing 'Choreography']
Through the air they keep flying, like a duck that is dying. Instead of dance, it's choreography.

[after Phil and Judy announce their engagement at the party]
I sure wish it would happen to me.
Yeah, I do, too.
Soldiers and WACs / The WACs who dressed in slacks / Dancing cheek-to-cheek and pants-to-pants.

[singing]
Even guys with two left feet come out all right if the girl is sweet.
Oh, no. You wouldn't do this to me.
Wouldn't do what?
After you dressed me up like a dame...

[singing "Gee I Wish I Was Back In The Army"]
A soldier out of luck / Was really never stuck / There's always someone higher up where you can pass the buck / Oh, gee, I wish I was back in the army.
You know, in some ways, you're far superior to my cocker spaniel.

[to the Haynes sisters]
Mr. Wallace was just saying how remarkable it was that Benny Haynes' sisters should have eyes...

[voice cracks]
... I-I-I mean, blue eyes. That is eyes, uh...
Nice out.
We're booked for the holidays.
Vermont, huh?
Oh, Vermont should be beautiful this time of the year, with all that snow.
Yeah, you know something?
What?
Vermont should be beautiful this time of the year, all that snow.
That's what I just said.
We seem to be getting a little mixed up.
Maybe it's the music.
Maybe it isn't only the music.
[General Waverly has told the jeep driver to take the new Commanding General back to Headquarters via "the short cut"]

[pointing after the departed jeep]
That's not the way back to Headquarters!
Joe, YOU know that, and I know that, but, uh, the General doesn't know it. At least he won't for about an hour and a half.
That sergeant will be a private in the morning.

[wearily]
Yes, isn't he lucky.

[after performing "Sisters"]
Hey, we're a smash. Let's take a bow!
You crazy? We'll be takin' a bow down at the jail house. Come on.

[about Bob's idea to help the General]
I think it's impossible, ridiculous and insane!
Anything else?
Yeah, I wish I'd thought of it first.
she's in love.
Well, if that's love, somebody goofed.

[describing his injury after "falling down the stairs"]
It's probably just a small internal muscular hemorrhage, sir.
Why here?
Well, you got this nice big empty ski lodge, and the minute Phil and I saw it, we thought it was ideal, didn't we, Phil?
Uh, that's right, Bob, ideal. That's exactly the word we used, too - ideal. We looked at this big ski lodge and we said "Isn't it ideal, absolutely, ideal," didn't we?
Ideal.
We've established the fact the lodge is ideal.

[after creating her phony engagement with Phil]
But, don't you think we ought to... oh... kiss or something?

[Obviously nervous]
Uh... n-n-not until it's absolutely necessary.
Mr. Bones? Mr. Bones? How do you feel, Mr. Bones?
Rattlin'!
Mr. Bones feels rattlin'. Ha ha. That's a good one. Tell a little story, Mr. Bones.
A funny little story, Mr. Bones!
How can you stop an angry dog from biting you on Monday?
That joke is old. The answer is to kill the dog on Sunday!
That's not the way to stop a dog from biting you on Monday!
How would you bring the thing about?
Have the doggy's teeth pulled out!
Oh, Mr. Bones, that's terrible!
Uh-huh.
Yes, Mr. Bones, that's terrible!
Uh-huh.
I got along very well in the Army without you.
It took 15,000 men to take m' place.
[after Bob has found out about Phil and Judy's phony engagement]
Well, ib... ib... ib... It's always that she's been kind of a mother hen.
Yeah, we wanted the mother hen to leave the roost so that the little chick could... Oh, I guess we laid an egg.
An egg? Brother, you laid a Vermont volleyball!
How could you have sent all my suits to the cleaners?

[laconically]
You've only got two.
Well, I think you'd send one at a time then, in that case.

[Looking at Judy; to Bob]
Hey, how about those big brown eyes?

[Looking at Betty]
No, they're blue.

[Still looking at Judy]
Brown.

[Still looking at Betty]
Uh-uh, blue.

[Follows Bob's gaze and sees Betty]
Oh, yeah. *Deep* blue.
We came up here for the snow. Where're you keepin' it?
Well, we take it in during the day!
[Susan and the General enter the ballroom to find two rows of soldiers forming a path to the stage]

[Steping up to the General and saluting]
Troops ready for inspection, sir!

[at his side]
Just routine, sir.

["inspecting the troops" at the inn]
I am not satisfied with the conduct of this division. Some of you men are under the impression having been at Anzio entitles you not to wear neckties. Well you're wrong. Neckties will be worn in this area! And look at the rest of your appearance. You're a disgrace to the outfit. You're soft! You're sloppy! You're unruly! You're undisciplined!
[pause]
And I never saw anything look so wonderful in my whole life! Thank you all.

[inquiring about the inn]
Well, are things really that bad?
We're using the ski tow to hang the wash on.
There's no Christmas in the Army, Captain.
[General Waverly has come downstairs for the Christmas Eve show in his uniform]

[to Susan]
You didn't expect me to come down in my bathrobe, did you?

[about Betty]
Mm-mm, but I got a flash for you.
What?
She's a real slow mover.
she's in there with the champ.

[attempting to button his uniform pants]
Captain, dis things haff shrunked!
Well, your appetite hasn't shrunk.

[to Capt. Wallace]
Don't just stand there - how do I get off?

[singing on the train]
I wanna wash my hands, my face, my hair with snow.
Gosh, I hope I can take the electric blanket back.
Where you got that?
Under the underwear.
Oh, you'll get a nice tan.
We ate, and then he ate. We slept, then he slept.
Yeah, then he woke up and nobody slept for forty-eight hours.

[Buying train tickets]
Uh, I don't seem to have any cash.
What did you do with THAT, leave it in your snood?

[Regarding the inn]
He sunk everything - his pension, his life savings - EVERYTHING in remodeling this place. Used to be a grist mill and a barn; now it's a Tyrolean haunted house.
Looks like it's absolutely necessary.

[to Phil]
Well, you're not exactly Superman, but you're awfully available.
Hey, Davis! How you feelin'?
Oh, pretty good, Captain.
I just dropped by to thank you for saving my life.
Well, it was a life worth saving, sir.
Look who's talkin' about guilt!
What do you mean by that?
I mean you shouldn't mix fairy tales with liverwurst and buttermilk.
What d'you have for lunch today?
I didn't have lunch.
Well, maybe you ought to eat some.
Why is everybody suddenly so concerned about my eating habits? Why don't people just leave me alone?
[last lines]

[singing]
... And may all your Christmases be white. MERRY CHRISTMAS!
[first lines]
Stop the jeep, Sergeant. What's this all about, Captain?
Let's face it, Bob. You're a lonely, miserable man.
What?
Well, break your arm, or your ankle or your neck but don't break anything valuable, huh?
Okay, Bob. You can depend on me.
Oh, my word, if I wasn't such a mean old biddy, I'd break right down and cry.

[after he learns that Betty and Judy has informed them they're singing in Vermont]
It sounds very Vermonty!
[Phil rolls his eyes after Bob discovers that's why they should change their holiday plans]
